title: Mountain Biking in North Wales
strapline: From gnarly downhill tracks to scenic forest trails, North Wales serves up a proper slice of mountain biking heaven.
metaTitle: Mountain Biking North Wales | Adventure Wales
metaDescription: Explore the best mountain biking in North Wales. Discover thrilling trails at Llandegla, Revolution Bike Park, and more. Plan your ride today!
heroAlt: Mountain biker riding a challenging trail through a forest in North Wales
introduction:
Alright, listen up, because when it comes to mountain biking, North Wales isn't just good, it's *iconic*. Forget those manicured bike park trails you find elsewhere. Here, we've got proper wild riding, proper mountains, and proper Welsh weather to keep you on your toes. If you're after a challenge, you've come to the right place. But don't be fooled; North Wales caters to all levels. From the beginner-friendly trails at Coed Llandegla to the expert-only downhill lines at Revolution Bike Park, there's something for everyone. The Marin Trail in Betws-y-Coed offers stunning views and flowy singletrack, while Penmachno is a hidden gem with challenging climbs and rewarding descents. 

That being said, it's not all sunshine and rainbows. The weather can turn on a dime, and some of the trails are seriously exposed. Pack accordingly, and don't underestimate the climbs – they're brutal! But trust me, the views from the top are worth every ounce of effort. Plus, the riding communities are incredibly welcoming and supportive. Hit up any trailhead on a weekend, and you'll find riders of all levels sharing tips, stories, and maybe even a puncture repair or two. If you’re serious about mountain biking, North Wales is the place to be. Come prepared, respect the trails, and you’ll have an unforgettable adventure.

spots.name: Revolution Bike Park
spots.description: Revolution Bike Park is the UK's premier downhill mountain bike park. Expect uplift service, gnarly tracks, big jumps, and seriously challenging features. Not for the faint of heart, but an absolute blast for experienced riders.
spots.bestFor: Experienced downhill mountain bikers looking for a challenge.
spots.notSuitableFor: Beginners or riders not comfortable with jumps and technical features.
spots.parking: Ample parking available at the bike park. Cost is included in uplift ticket.
spots.insiderTip: Book your uplift in advance, especially on weekends, as it often sells out.

spots.name: Coed Llandegla (Oneplanet Adventure)
spots.description: Coed Llandegla offers a great mix of trails for all abilities, from gentle green routes to challenging red and black runs. Excellent facilities, including a cafe, bike shop, and bike wash. A perfect starting point for mountain biking in North Wales.
spots.notSuitableFor: Those looking for extreme downhill or very technical riding (outside of the black runs).
spots.parking: Large car park at Oneplanet Adventure. Charges apply (approx £5-7 per day).
spots.insiderTip: Park closer to the exit if you want to leave quickly at the end of the day. The cafe can get busy so have some snacks just in case.

spots.name: Marin Trail (Betws-y-Coed)
spots.description: The Marin Trail is a classic North Wales mountain bike route, offering stunning views and flowy singletrack. A challenging climb is rewarded with exhilarating descents. Be prepared for rocky sections and varied terrain.
spots.bestFor: Intermediate to experienced riders looking for a classic trail ride.
spots.notSuitableFor: Beginners or those uncomfortable with steep climbs and rocky descents.
spots.parking: Pay and display car park in Betws-y-Coed. Can get busy, especially during peak season.
spots.insiderTip: Take a breather at the top of the climb – the views are incredible. Pack a repair kit and pump – punctures are common on the rocky sections.

spots.name: Penmachno Trails
spots.description: Penmachno is a hidden gem with two fantastic trail loops: Dolen Machno and Dolen Eryri. Expect challenging climbs, rewarding descents, and stunning views of Snowdonia. A great alternative to the more popular trails.
spots.bestFor: Intermediate to experienced riders looking for a quieter trail ride.
spots.notSuitableFor: Beginners or those uncomfortable with steep climbs and technical sections.
spots.parking: Free parking available at the trailhead. Limited spaces, so arrive early.
spots.insiderTip: Bring midge repellent, especially in the evenings. The descents are fast and flowy – enjoy!

spots.name: Gwydir Mawr (formerly The Beast)
spots.description: Gwydir Mawr, close to Betws-y-Coed, features challenging climbs and demanding descents through dense forest. Expect steep gradients, technical rock gardens, and some fantastic views. Make sure your brakes are working properly!
spots.bestFor: Experienced riders looking for a technical and challenging ride.
spots.notSuitableFor: Beginners or those uncomfortable with steep, technical terrain.
spots.parking: Parking available at various points along the trail. Check trail maps for details.
spots.insiderTip: The trail can be very muddy after rain, so check the weather forecast before you go. The descent to Llyn Elsi can be very slippery.

spots.name: Clwydian Range
spots.description: The Clwydian Range offers stunning views and varied terrain, with options for both challenging climbs and fast descents. Explore ancient hillforts and enjoy panoramic vistas of the North Wales coastline. Bring your camera!
spots.bestFor: Intermediate riders looking for scenic trails and challenging climbs.
spots.notSuitableFor: Beginners may find some sections challenging. Be prepared for exposed conditions.
spots.parking: Parking available at various points along the range. Loggerheads Country Park is a good starting point.
spots.insiderTip: Check the weather forecast before you go, as the range can be very exposed. The views from Moel Famau are incredible.

spots.name: Clocaenog Forest
spots.description: Clocaenog Forest offers a network of forest roads and singletrack trails, perfect for exploring the Welsh countryside. Expect varied terrain, challenging climbs, and rewarding descents. A great option for a longer ride.
spots.bestFor: Intermediate riders looking for a longer ride through varied terrain.
spots.notSuitableFor: Beginners may find some sections challenging. Be prepared for remote conditions.
spots.parking: Parking available at various points around the forest. Check trail maps for details.
spots.insiderTip: The forest can be very muddy after rain, so check the weather forecast before you go. Bring a map and compass, as the trails can be confusing.

spots.name: Coastal Trails near Llandudno
spots.description: While not strictly 'mountain' biking, the coastal paths around Llandudno offer fantastic views and a more relaxed riding experience. Expect some climbs, but mostly relatively flat terrain. Great for a family ride or a scenic spin.
spots.bestFor: Families, beginners, and those looking for a scenic ride with stunning coastal views.
spots.notSuitableFor: Experienced mountain bikers looking for technical challenges.
spots.parking: Parking available in Llandudno and along the coast.
spots.insiderTip: Stop for an ice cream in Llandudno after your ride. Check the tide times before you go, as some sections of the coastal path can be affected by high tide.

practicalInfo.weather: The weather in North Wales can be unpredictable, even in summer. Rain is common, and the mountains can be significantly colder and windier than the valleys. Check the forecast before you go, and be prepared for all conditions.
gearChecklist: Mountain bike in good working order
Appropriate clothing – layers are key, including a waterproof jacket
Bike repair kit – including spare tube, pump, and multi-tool
Water and snacks – stay hydrated and fueled!
Map or GPS device – don't get lost!
First-aid kit – be prepared for minor injuries
Midge repellent – essential in the summer months
Phone - fully charged, in a waterproof bag

gettingThere.publicTransport: Direct trains to Llandudno, Bangor, and Betws-y-Coed. Local bus services connect many of the towns and villages. The Snowdon Sherpa bus service provides access to many of the popular hiking and biking trails.
gettingThere.parkingTips: Parking can be limited, especially during peak season. Arrive early to secure a space, or consider using public transport. Be aware of parking restrictions and charges.

practicalInfo.safety: Mountain biking can be a dangerous activity. Always wear a helmet and appropriate protective gear. Ride within your abilities, and be aware of your surroundings. Check the weather forecast before you go, and be prepared for all conditions. Tell someone where you are going and when you expect to be back. Emergency contact: 999 for police, fire, or ambulance. Mountain Rescue: 112.

faqs.question: What is the best mountain bike trail in North Wales for beginners?
faqs.answer: Coed Llandegla is a fantastic option for beginners, with well-maintained green and blue trails. The trails are relatively flat and easy to navigate, making it a great place to learn the basics.

faqs.question: How much does it cost to go mountain biking in Revolution Bike Park?
faqs.answer: A full day's uplift pass at Revolution Bike Park typically costs between £45 and £55. Booking in advance is highly recommended.

faqs.question: What gear do I need for mountain biking in North Wales?
faqs.answer: Essential gear includes a mountain bike in good working order, a helmet, gloves, appropriate clothing (including a waterproof jacket), a bike repair kit, water, and snacks. A map or GPS device is also recommended.

faqs.question: Are there any bike shops in Betws-y-Coed?
faqs.answer: Yes, Beics Betws is a well-known bike shop in Betws-y-Coed, offering bike hire, sales, and repairs. They also have a good selection of accessories and clothing.

faqs.question: What is the best time of year to go mountain biking in North Wales?
faqs.answer: The best time of year to go mountain biking in North Wales is from April to October. The weather is generally drier and warmer during these months, but be prepared for rain at any time of year.

faqs.question: Are there any guided mountain bike tours in North Wales?
faqs.answer: Yes, several companies offer guided mountain bike tours in North Wales, including Oneplanet Adventure at Coed Llandegla. Guided tours are a great way to explore the trails and improve your skills.

faqs.question: Where can I find the Marin Trail in North Wales?
faqs.answer: The Marin Trail is located near Betws-y-Coed. The trail starts from the car park in Betws-y-Coed and is well signposted. It is a 25km loop with around 680m of elevation gain.

gearShops.name: Beics Betws
gearShops.address: Station Buildings, Holyhead Road, Betws-y-Coed LL24 0BL
gearShops.description: The go-to shop in Betws-y-Coed for bike hire, sales, and repairs. Stock a good range of bikes and accessories, plus knowledgeable staff.

gearShops.name: Oneplanet Adventure Shop
gearShops.address: Coed Llandegla Forest, Llandegla, Wrexham LL11 3AA
gearShops.description: Located at Coed Llandegla, this shop offers bike hire, sales, repairs, and accessories. Convenient for anyone riding the trails there.

gearShops.name: Trek Bicycle Wrexham
gearShops.address: Unit A1, Wrexham Technology Park, Wrexham LL13 7YP
gearShops.description: Specializing in Trek bikes, this shop offers a wide range of bikes, clothing, and accessories. Also provides servicing and repairs.

gearShops.name: Rutland Cycling - Porth Eirias
gearShops.address: Porth Eirias, Promenade, Colwyn Bay LL29 8HH
gearShops.description: Located right on the coast, this Rutland Cycling branch provides sales, hire, and repairs. Suited for coastal path and road cycling needs.

gearShops.name: Gorilla Bikes
gearShops.description: An independent bike shop in Llanberis offering sales, repairs and hire.

postActivitySpots.name: The Cafe at Coed Llandegla
postActivitySpots.address: Coed Llandegla Forest, Llandegla, Wrexham LL11 3AA
postActivitySpots.description: The perfect spot for refuelling after a ride at Coed Llandegla. Serves hot and cold food, drinks, and snacks. Known for its bacon butties and cakes.

postActivitySpots.name: Y Stablau Stable Bar
postActivitySpots.description: A cosy pub in Betws-y-Coed, perfect for a post-ride pint and a hearty meal. Known for its real ales and pub classics.

postActivitySpots.name: Moel Siabod Cafe
postActivitySpots.description: Popular cafe in Capel Curig, serving breakfasts, lunches, and cakes. A great spot for refuelling before or after a ride.
postActivitySpots.knownFor: Breakfasts, cakes, views of Moel Siabod

postActivitySpots.name: Caffi Siabod
postActivitySpots.address: Pont Cyfyng, Capel Curig, Betws-y-Coed LL24 0DS
postActivitySpots.description: Another Capel Curig gem, offering hearty portions, friendly service, and stunning views. Great for a post-ride feast.

postActivitySpots.name: Hangin' Pizzeria
postActivitySpots.description: Wood fired pizza and craft beer in Betws-y-Coed. A popular place for bikers after the trails.

postActivitySpots.name: The Eagles Inn
postActivitySpots.description: A traditional country pub in Penmachno, perfect after tackling the Penmachno trails. Good food and a friendly atmosphere.

accommodation.name: Plas Curig Hostel
accommodation.description: Budget-friendly hostel in Capel Curig, close to many popular mountain biking trails. Ideal for groups and solo travelers.

accommodation.name: Bryn Gloch Caravan & Camping Park
accommodation.description: Camping and caravan park near Betws-y-Coed, offering stunning views and easy access to the Marin Trail and Gwydir Forest.

accommodation.name: The Royal Oak Hotel
accommodation.description: A comfortable hotel in Betws-y-Coed, offering well-appointed rooms and a restaurant. A great base for exploring the area.

accommodation.name: Ty Isaf B&B
accommodation.description: A charming B&B in Penmachno, perfect for those riding the Penmachno trails. Offers comfortable rooms and a delicious breakfast.

accommodation.name: Gwern Gôf Isaf Campsite
accommodation.description: Very basic and famous climbers campsite located in the Ogwen Valley. Great for a budget option close to the trails.

accommodation.name: Tyn Cornel Hotel
accommodation.description: A popular spot in Snowdonia close to several mountain biking trails.

events.name: Welsh Enduro Series
events.description: A series of enduro mountain bike races held at various locations throughout Wales.

events.name: Marin Trail Challenge
events.description: An annual mountain bike race held on the Marin Trail in Betws-y-Coed.

events.name: Red Bull Hardline
events.description: One of the toughest downhill mountain bike races in the world, held in Dyfi Forest, Mid Wales. (Nearby enough to be relevant to the area)
